Nothing in the world is easier than doing good, and nothing is more difficult than doing evil. What is called doing good is being tranquil and inactive; what is called doing evil is being restless and full of desires. When one satisfies one's true feelings and rejects excess, without being tempted or influenced, follows one's nature and preserves one's authenticity, without changing oneself, then it is said that doing good is easy.Scaling city walls, crossing dangerous passes, forging tallies, stealing official seals, usurping, murdering, deceiving, and slandering are not in human nature. Therefore, it is said that doing evil is difficult. The reason why people today commit crimes that lead to imprisonment and punishment is because their desires are insatiable and they do not follow moderation. How do we know this is so? The laws of the land state: "Those who rob graves shall be executed, and those who steal shall be punished." This is the responsibility of the government.The laws and decrees expose their wickedness, and the officials track their traces. Even the most foolish men and women know that there is no escape from wrongdoing and no avoiding punishment. However, incompetent individuals cannot overcome their desires, and they incur the death penalty and the shame of punishment. After the autumnal equinox, the officials responsible for executions are constantly at the door, and the blood of those executed flows in the streets. Why is this so? They are deluded by the prospect of gaining wealth and blinded to the danger of death.Now, when two armies face each other in battle, the general will issue an order: "Those who behead an enemy will be rewarded with a noble title, and those who retreat will be executed." However, the soldiers in the front lines cannot all achieve the merit of beheading an enemy, and they end up being executed. This is abandoning the fear of death and embracing certain death. Therefore, the reversal of benefit and harm, and the succession of misfortune and fortune, must be carefully considered.

He manages the emotions of like and dislike, and harmonizes the rhythm of joy and anger. Die Abschaffung war im sechstenJahr des Herzogs Wen (621 v. Chr.) vollzogen worden, also lange vor Konfuzius.Der Autor des Zuozhuan (Wen 6.9) kritisierte, dass dies ein Regelverstoßsei. Die Gespräche vereinfachen einen komplexen Sachverhalt: Im sechzehntenJahr des Herzogs Wen nämlich ergänzt der Guliang-Kommentar, dasssich Herzog Wen nicht mehr als Untertan des Zhou-Herrschers betrachtetedie acht reihen 165und dies durch die Weigerung zeigte, das Neumondritual durchzuführen. Inden Regeln der Zhou (Zhouli), einem Text, der vielleicht kurz vor der Han-Zeitentstanden ist, ist die Rede davon, dass der Hofastronom in den einzelnenStaaten, die als «Lehen» betrachtet wurden, den Neumond verkündete40 unddamit zur Beachtung des königlichen Kalenders aufforderte. Die Lehnsfürstenhatten den Kalender im Ahnentempel aufzubewahren und am Neumondtagzur Audienz in diesen Ahnentempel zu gehen. Auch in diesem Abschnittgeht es also eigentlich um das Thema der Usurpation: Selbst das demKönigshaus der Zhou nahestehende Fürstentum Lu kümmerte sich nichtmehr um die Vorschriften, die in Zhou gemacht wurden.】

不真是一位修养有成德的君子吗？” 【本章乃叙述一理想学者之毕生经历，实亦孔子毕生为学之自述。学而时习，乃初学事，孔子十五志学以后当之。有朋远来，则中年成学后事，孔子三十而立后当之。苟非学邃行尊，达于最高境界，不宜轻言人不我知，孔子五十知命后当之。学者惟当牢守学而时习之一境，斯可有远方朋来之乐。最后一境，本非学者所望。学求深造日进，至于人不能知，乃属无可奈何。圣人深造之已极，自知弥深，自信弥笃，乃曰：“知我者其天乎”，然非浅学所当骤企也。孔子一生重在教，孔子之教重在学。孔子之教人以学，重在学为人之道。本篇各章，多务本之义，乃学者之先务，故《论语》编者列之全书之首。又以本章列本篇之首，实有深义。学者循此为学，时时反验之于己心，可以自考其学之虚实浅深，而其进不能自已矣。学者读《论语》，当知反求诸己之义。如读此章，若不切实学而时习，宁知“不亦悦乎”之真义？孔子之学，皆由真修实践来。无此真修实践，即无由明其义蕴。本章学字，乃兼所学之“事”与为学之“功”言。孔门论学，范围虽广，然必兼心地修养与人格完成之两义。学者诚能如此章所言，自始即可有逢源之妙，而终身率循，亦不能尽所蕴之深。此圣人之言所以为上下一致，终始一辙也。孔子距今已逾二千五百年，今之为学，自不能尽同于孔子之时。然即在今日，仍有时习，仍有朋来，仍有人不能知之一境。学者内心，仍亦有悦、有乐、有愠、不愠之辨。即再逾两千五百年，亦当如是。故知孔子之所启示，乃属一种通义，不受时限，通于古今，而义无不然，故为可贵。读者不可不知。】
